articles.headline: What to Expect When You’re Expecting: Supply Chain Issues
articles.snippet: Expectant parents have keenly felt the inconvenience of global shipping delays caused by the pandemic. With a baby due, “it’s a different ballgame.”
articles.abstract: Expectant parents have keenly felt the inconvenience of global shipping delays caused by the pandemic. With a baby due, “it’s a different ballgame.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as Eryn Yates made it through her first trimester of pregnancy last spring, she started shopping for her dream nursery.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: What Social Trends Told Us About the American Economy in 2021
articles.snippet: “Hard pants,” R.T.O. and boomer burnout made for an eventful second pandemic year. They also taught us about the economic future.
articles.abstract: “Hard pants,” R.T.O. and boomer burnout made for an eventful second pandemic year. They also taught us about the economic future.
articles.lead_paragraph: If 2020 was the year that made Zoom a verb and imbued the phrase “online dating” with new meaning, 2021 was its annoying younger sibling. Things were not quite as novel and scary as the darkest early days of the pandemic and initial state and local lockdowns, but the year found new and creative ways to be bad.

articles.headline: Ungerrymandered: Michigan’s Maps, Independently Drawn, Set Up Fair Fight
articles.snippet: A citizen ballot initiative took redistricting out of the hands of partisan legislators. The result: competitive political districts — and an example of how to push back against hyperpartisanship.
articles.abstract: A citizen ballot initiative took redistricting out of the hands of partisan legislators. The result: competitive political districts — and an example of how to push back against hyperpartisanship.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most gerrymandered political maps has suddenly been replaced by one of the fairest.

articles.headline: Everybody Into the Metaverse! Virtual Reality Beckons Big Tech.
articles.snippet: Tech’s biggest companies are joining game makers and start-ups in pursuit of an immersive digital world that some have been working on for years.
articles.abstract: Tech’s biggest companies are joining game makers and start-ups in pursuit of an immersive digital world that some have been working on for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The metaverse, one of the most buzzy terms of the tech industry, could be many things. It could be a virtual world where imagination is the only limit. Or it could be a less fantastical place for holding business meetings without leaving home.

articles.headline: After 4 Killings, ‘Officer of the Year’ Is Still on the Job
articles.snippet: A Pennsylvania state trooper was returned to duty following three investigations by his own agency. A fourth inquiry is underway.
articles.abstract: A Pennsylvania state trooper was returned to duty following three investigations by his own agency. A fourth inquiry is underway.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEBANON, Pa. — In November 2008, Pennsylvania Trooper Jay Splain was honored at a county law enforcement banquet as a hero, the police officer of the year. The reason: He had shot and killed a suicidal man who allegedly pointed an Uzi submachine gun at him.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: The Metaverse’s Dark Side: Here Come Harassment and Assaults
articles.snippet: As Meta and other companies bet big on an immersive digital world, questions about its harms are rising.
articles.abstract: As Meta and other companies bet big on an immersive digital world, questions about its harms are rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Chanelle Siggens recently strapped on an Oculus Quest virtual reality headset to play her favorite shooter game, Population One. Once she turned on the game, she maneuvered her avatar into a virtual lobby in the immersive digital world and waited for the action to begin.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: As At-Home Tests Surge, Doubts Rise About Accuracy of Public Covid Counts
articles.snippet: Most of the results of rapid tests are not reported. That’s magnifying questions about how best to measure the spread of the virus.
articles.abstract: Most of the results of rapid tests are not reported. That’s magnifying questions about how best to measure the spread of the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of rapid at-home Covid tests are flying off pharmacy shelves across the country, giving Americans an instant, if sometimes imperfect, read on whether they are infected with the coronavirus.

articles.headline: Can a Tiny Territory in the South Pacific Power Tesla’s Ambitions?
articles.snippet: Nickel is vital to electric car batteries, but extracting it is dirty and destructive. A plant with a turbulent history in New Caledonia is about to become an experiment in doing it better.
articles.abstract: Nickel is vital to electric car batteries, but extracting it is dirty and destructive. A plant with a turbulent history in New Caledonia is about to become an experiment in doing it better.
articles.lead_paragraph: GORO, New Caledonia — From the reef-fringed coast of New Caledonia, the Coral Sea stretches into the South Pacific. Slender native pines, listing like whimsical Christmas trees, punctuate the shoreline. The landscape, one of the most biodiverse on the planet, is astonishingly beautiful until the crest of a hill where a different vista unfolds: a gouged red earth pierced by belching smokestacks and giant trucks rumbling across the lunar-like terrain.
